ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ABSENT=number | qs] 
      
Specifies the value to be used as an absence value in an irrelevant absent-absent match 
for all of the asymmetric nominal variables.

[Syntax: ADD=c] 
      
Specifies a constant, c, to add to each value after standardizing and multiplying by the 
value you specify in the MULT= option. The default value is 0.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the input data set containing observations from which the proximity is computed.

[Syntax: FUZZ=c] 
      
Specifies the relative fuzz factor for computing the standardized scores. The default 
value is 1E–14.

[Syntax: INITIAL=method] 
      
Specifies the method of computing initial estimates for the A-estimates (ABW, 
AWAVE, and AHUBER). The following methods are not allowed for the INITIAL= 
option: ABW, AHUBER, AWAVE, and IN. 

The default value is INITIAL=MAD.
Specifies the method of computing proximity measures.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Euclidean distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Squared Euclidean distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Size distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Shape distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Covariance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Correlation
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Correlation transformed to Euclidean distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Squared correlation
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] One minus squared correlation
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Minkowski (Lp) distance,  where p is a positive numeric value
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] L1, city-block, or Manhattan distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip14: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] L(infinity)
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip15: [Accepts ratio, interval, and ordinal variables] Generalized Euclidean distance where p is a positive numeric value and r is a nonnegative numeric value.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip16: [Accepts ratio variables] Similarity ratio (if variables are binary,  this is the Jaccard coefficient)
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip17: [Accepts ratio variables] One minus similarity ratio
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip18: [Accepts ratio variables] Lance and Williams nonmetric coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip19: [Accepts ratio variables] Canberra metric distance coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip25: [Accepts ratio variables] Square root of chi-square coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip27: [Accepts ratio variables] Square root of Φ² coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip30: [Accepts nominal variables] Simple matching coefficient transformed to Euclidean distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip31: [Accepts nominal variables] Simple matching coefficient transformed to squared Euclidean distance
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip36: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Dice coefficient or Czekanowski/Sorensen similarity coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip37: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Russell and Rao
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip38: [Accepts asymmetric nominal variables] Binary Lance and Williams nonmetric,  or Bray-Curtis coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip40: [Accepts asymmetric nominal and ratio variables] Jaccard similarity coefficient
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip41: [Accepts asymmetric nominal and ratio variables] Jaccard dissimilarity coefficient

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MULT=c] 
      
Specifies a numeric constant, c, by which to multiply each value after standardizing. 
The default value is 1.

Omits observations with missing values from computation of the location and scale 
measures when standardizing; generates undefined (missing) distances for 
observations with missing values when computing distances.

Normalizes the scale estimator to be consistent for the standard deviation of a 
normal distribution when you specify the option STD=AGK, STD=IQR, STD=MAD, or 
STD=SPACING in the VAR statement.

Suppresses standardization of the variables. The NOSTD option should not be specified
with the STDONLY option or with the REPLACE option.

[Syntax: PREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming the distance variables in the OUT= data set. By default,
the names are Dist1, Dist2, ..., Dist. If you specify PREFIX=ABC, the variables are 
named ABC1, ABC2, ..., ABCn.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the name of the SAS data set created by PROC DISTANCE.

[Syntax: OUTSDZ=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the name of the SAS data set containing the standardized scores.
Specifies the method of assigning scores to ordinal variables.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Assigns consecutive integers to each category with consideration of the frequency value.  This is the default method.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Assigns consecutive integers to each category regardless of frequencies.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Replaces missing data with zero in the standardized data (to correspond to the location
measure before standardizing).

Replaces missing data with the location measure specified by the MISSING= option or the 
STD= option (if the MISSING= option is not specified), but does not standardize the data.
Specifies the shape of the proximity matrix to be stored in the OUT= data set.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: SHAPE=TRIANGLE requests the matrix to be stored as a lower triangular matrix.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: SHAPE=SQUARE requests that the matrix be stored as a squared matrix.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Normalizes the scale estimator to have an expectation of approximately 1 for a 
standard normal distribution when the STD=SPACING option is specified.

Standardizes variables only and computes no distance matrix. You must use the OUTSDZ= 
option to save the standardized scores. You cannot specify both the STDONLY option 
and the NOSTD option.

[Syntax: UNDEF=n] 
      
Specifies the numeric constant used to replace undefined distances, such as when 
an observation has all missing values, or if a divisor is zero.

Specifies the divisor to be used in the calculation of distance, dissimilarity, or 
similarity measures, and for standardizing variables whenever a variance or 
covariance is computed.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: VAR level ( variables < / opt-list> ) 
    < level ( variables < / opt-list> ) ...level ( variables < / opt-list> ) > ; 

where the syntax for the opt-list is as follows: 

  ABSENT=value 
  MISSING=miss-method | value 
  ORDER=order-option 
  STD=std-method 
  WEIGHTS=weight-list 
  
The VAR statement lists variables from which distances are to be computed. The VAR 
statement is required. The variables can be numeric or character depending on their 
measurement levels. A variable cannot appear more than once in either the same list 
or a different list.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[level value] 
          
Variables are asymmetric nominal and can be either numeric or character.

[level value] 
          
Variables are symmetric nominal and can be either numeric or character.

[level value] 
          
Variables are ordinal and can be either numeric or character.

[level value] 
          
Variables are interval and numeric.

[level value] 
          
Variables are ratio and numeric. Ratio variables should always contain positive measurements.

[Syntax: ABSENT=numner | qs] 
          
Specifies the value to be used as an absence value in an irrelevant absent-absent
match for asymmetric nominal variables.

[Syntax: MISSING=miss-method | value] 
          
Specifies the method (or numeric value) with which to replace missing data.]
Selects the order for assigning scores to ordinal variables. ]

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Scores are assigned in lowest-to-highest order of unformatted values. This is the default.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Scores are assigned in highest-to-lowest order of unformatted values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Scores are assigned in ascending order by their formatted values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Scores are assigned in descending order by their formatted values.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Scores are assigned according to the order of their appearance in the input data set.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: WEIGHTS=weight-list] 
          
Assigns weights to the variables in the list.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: WEIGHT variable;
      
The WEIGHT statement specifies a numeric variable in the input data set with values 
that are used to weight each observation. This weight variable is used for standardizing 
variables rather than computing the distances. Only one variable can be specified.
